channel.title: Latest alerts from washingtonpost.com
channel.description: An unofficial feed created by Derek Willis.

item.title: ICC issues arrest warrants for Netanyahu and Gallant, accusing them of war crimes in Gaza, and a Hamas commander for Oct. 7 attacks
item.description: The International Criminal Court said it found reasonable grounds to believe that Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and former defense minister Yoav Gallant were responsible for war crimes and crimes against humanity in Gaza, including using starvation as a method of warfare and directing attacks against civilians. Both men have vehemently denied the allegations. The court also issued a warrant for Hamas commander Mohammed Deif for crimes against humanity committed on Oct. 7. Israel said it killed Deif in a July airstrike but the ICC said it had not confirmed his death.

item.title: Elon Musk. Matt Gaetz. Google Chrome. Israeli weapons. Egg shortage. AI power demands. EagleCam. Catch up now.
item.description: Catch up in minutes with these 7 stories.

item.title: Justice Dept. seeks to force Google to sell its Chrome browser, along with other big changes, in monopoly case
item.description: The filing from federal prosecutors is one of the last expressions of President Joe Biden’s aggressive antitrust stance before President-elect Donald Trump takes the reins.

item.title: Connecticut women's basketball coach Geno Auriemma sets record for most wins in college basketball history
item.description: Auriemma achieved the milestone Wednesday night, passing former Stanford women's coach Tara VanDerveer with his 1,217th victory. Auriemma, who has spent his entire 40-year career as a head coach at Connecticut, has won 11 national championships and made 22 Final Four appearances.

item.title: How a brutally repressive African country freely raises money in the U.S.
item.description: Three years ago, the United States imposed sanctions against the ruling party of Eritrea, a small country in the Horn of Africa. And yet, Eritrea’s embassy in Washington has helped raise millions of dollars on behalf of the cash-strapped country since then, while Eritrean officials acknowledge that the government and the ruling party are one.

item.title: Man pleads guilty to killing three University of Virginia classmates on a bus in 2022
item.description: Christopher Darnell Jones Jr. was arrested in November 2022 after authorities say he opened fire on a bus carrying U-Va. students as they returned to the Charlottesville campus from a field trip in D.C. D’Sean Perry, Lavel Davis Jr. and Devin Chandler were killed, and two other students were injured.

item.title: House panel saw records suggesting Gaetz paid two women $10,000, in part for sex, according to a person familiar with investigation
item.description: The records that were exhibited during closed-door testimony displayed 27 different PayPal and Venmo payments totaling over $10,000 paid to the two witnesses, the person said. The House Ethics Committee investigated whether former congressman Matt Gaetz, President-elect Donald Trump’s pick to run the Justice Department, paid for sex with a 17-year-old and now faces calls to release its findings.

item.title: Carolyn Hax: He’s a great boyfriend, the one night a week he’s free
item.description: Carolyn Hax: He’s a great boyfriend, the one night a week he’s free

item.title: Dining chat: Does Michelin Guide recognition still matter? Our food critic responds and answers your questions.
item.description: Dining chat: Does Michelin Guide recognition still matter? Our food critic responds and answers your questions.

item.title: Venezuelan national found guilty of murdering nursing student Laken Riley in case that inflamed immigration debate
item.description: Jose Ibarra, an undocumented immigrant, was accused of murdering the University of Georgia student while she was on a run. Republicans made Riley’s death a national flash point ahead of the election.

item.title: RFK Jr. wants fluoride out of drinking water. Oregon shows what’s coming.
item.description: Fluoride is added to water to strengthen teeth and reduce cavities. Now more Americans are starting to question a practice experts have lauded as one of the greatest public health achievements of the 20th century.

item.title: ‘Cosmic justice’ in today’s On the Record
item.description: Answer now to earn your Wednesday points.

item.title: U.S. moves to protect giraffes under the Endangered Species Act by restricting imports of their body parts
item.description: The U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service announced a proposal Wednesday to protect a wide swath of giraffes for the first time, as the long-necked animals decline because of poaching, development and drought fueled by climate change.

item.title: Linda McMahon. Trump’s hush money case. Ukraine mines. Starship splashdown. Snow. Climate risk. Nadal’s farewell. Catch up now.
item.description: Catch up in minutes with these 7 stories.

item.title: Trump selects transition co-chair Linda McMahon to be education secretary
item.description: McMahon led the Small Business Administration from 2017 to 2019 and is the co-founder and former chief executive of World Wrestling Entertainment.

item.title: Biden approves antipersonnel land mines for Ukraine, reversing his 2022 policy and drawing criticism from arms control groups
item.description: The decision comes after the White House recently authorized Ukraine to use a long-range missile system to strike inside Russia — part of a sweep of urgent actions the outgoing Biden administration is taking to boost Kyiv’s faltering war effort.

item.title: Truth Social investors hoped to get ‘very rich’ after Trump’s win. Instead, they ‘are in trouble.’
item.description: Trump Media & Technology Group’s revenue and share price have sagged as its losses have piled up. The president-elect’s return to the White House could complicate things even more.

item.title: With Trump in attendance, Elon Musk’s SpaceX aborts a second attempt to re-capture Starship booster at launch pad
item.description: A SpaceX Starship rocket splashed down in the Gulf of Mexico on Tuesday after the company aborted its second attempt to “catch” the returning booster at the launch pad — a disappointing outcome to a test mission observed by President-elect Donald Trump, who traveled to Texas to watch

item.title: Trump picks celebrity doctor Mehmet Oz to serve as administrator of the Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services
item.description: President-elect Donald Trump announced his plans to nominate the onetime U.S. Senate candidate in Pennsylvania to lead the agency that administers the Medicare and Medicaid programs. “I have known Dr. Oz for many years, and I am confident he will fight to ensure everyone in America receives the best possible Healthcare, so our Country can be Great and Healthy Again!” Trump said in a statement.

item.title: Texas education officials back optional Bible lessons in public elementary schools
item.description: The Texas State Board of Education voted 8-7 to move forward with approval for the optional curriculum, which opponents say promotes Christian beliefs in public school. The final vote is scheduled for Friday.

item.title: Carolyn Hax: Do they apologize for mocking in-law’s ‘weird’ Thanksgiving meal?
item.description: Carolyn Hax: Do they apologize for mocking in-law’s ‘weird’ Thanksgiving meal?

item.title: Documents with damaging testimony against Matt Gaetz were accessed in an apparent breach
item.description: President-elect Donald Trump’s pick to run the Department of Justice was investigated on allegations of sexual misconduct with a 17-year-old girl; he was never charged.

item.title: Trump is expected to name Wall Street banker Howard Lutnick as commerce secretary, people familiar say
item.description: Lutnick, who serves as co-chair of President-elect Donald Trump’s transition team, had been under consideration for treasury secretary. He is the CEO and chairman of Cantor Fitzgerald, an investment firm, and has donated to both Democrats and Republicans in the past. He also once appeared on Trump’s NBC reality TV show, “The Apprentice.”

item.title: An unlikely find in Australia is the topic of today’s On the Record
item.description: Answer now to earn your Tuesday points.

item.title: Ukraine used U.S.-made ATACMS missiles inside Russia for the first time, according to Russian and Ukrainian officials
item.description: A Ukrainian official confirmed the ATACMS missiles were used inside Russia overnight. Russia said it shot down five of the six missiles fired at a facility in the Bryansk region. The attack comes soon after the Biden administration lifted restrictions on the use of the powerful, long-range, guided missiles inside Russia, long a Ukrainian request.

item.title: Matt Gaetz. Trump’s plans. Gaza gangs. Hong Kong. Atmospheric river. Doctors and AI. Wave power. Catch up now.
item.description: Catch up in minutes with these 7 stories.

item.title: Hong Kong sentences 45 pro-democracy leaders to jail terms of up to 10 years, including the city’s most prominent activists
item.description: Benny Tai, a 60-year-old legal scholar who spearheaded the Occupy Central movement, received the harshest sentence. Former student activist Joshua Wong, one of the most recognizable of the group, was sentenced to four years and eight months.

item.title: Trump picks former congressman and Fox Business host Sean Duffy as transportation secretary
item.description: Duffy, a former reality TV star who was elected to the House in 2010, will head a department that oversees the funding of roads, bridges and rail lines, as well as the running of the aviation system — and that plays a major role in overseeing companies run by billionaire Elon Musk.

item.title: Two women told House Ethics Committee that Matt Gaetz paid them for sex, lawyer says
item.description: Donald Trump’s pick for attorney general has been met with shock and pushback, including from Senate Republicans. Some have raised doubts that Gaetz would have the 50 votes needed to be confirmed.

item.title: Gangs looting aid convoys in Gaza operate in areas under Israeli military control, humanitarian officials say
item.description: Criminal looting near Israel’s Kerem Shalom crossing has become the greatest impediment to distributing aid in the southern half of Gaza, aid groups say, amid a deepening hunger crisis. The gangs “may be benefiting from a passive if not active benevolence” or “protection” from the Israeli military, according to an October U.N. memo obtained by The Washington Post.

item.title: The Smithsonian quietly removed the American Art Museum director this summer after years of staff complaints about her management style
item.description: The Smithsonian Institution placed Stephanie Stebich in a role as a senior adviser after Smithsonian American Art Museum staff complained of feeling frustrated and confused, according to interviews with current and former museum employees and an internal email confirming her job change.

item.title: Virginia Attorney General Jason Miyares (R) announces he’s running for reelection, not governor, in 2025
item.description: By running for reelection, Miyares avoids a potentially expensive and bruising gubernatorial primary with fellow Republican Lt. Gov. Winsome Earle-Sears, who has already announced her campaign to succeed the term-limited Gov. Glenn Youngkin (R).

item.title: Carolyn Hax: Late mother’s best friend was like a second mom — till she vanished
item.description: Carolyn Hax: Late mother’s best friend was like a second mom — till she vanished

item.title: Republicans are exploring significant changes to Medicaid and food stamps to help offset the cost of extending Trump’s tax cuts
item.description: Continuing the 2017 tax law would cost trillions. Seeking some budget savings, GOP lawmakers say safety net spending has ballooned.

item.title: Congress must stop offensive weapons sales to Israel, Sen. Bernie Sanders writes
item.description: Continuing to provide Israel with the offensive weapons it uses on civilians is morally wrong.

item.title: A taped message has solved the mystery of a World War I doughboy’s death
item.description: Foster Stevens was killed nine days before the Nov. 11, 1918, armistice that ended the Great War. Now his family knows about the man who was with him when he died.

item.title: A masterpiece restored in today’s On the Record
item.description: Answer now to earn your Monday points.

item.title: Trump’s team. Ukraine weapons. Pope Francis. Carrot recall. Spirit Airlines. Ancient kitten. Gladiator Airbnb. Catch up now.
item.description: Catch up in minutes with these 7 stories.

item.title: Spirit Airlines files for bankruptcy, says it will continue to operate as it seeks to restructure its debt
item.description: “Spirit expects to continue operating its business in the normal course throughout this prearranged, streamlined chapter 11 process,” it said in a release. “Guests can continue to book and fly without interruption and can use all tickets, credits and loyalty points as normal.”

item.title: Trump picks Brendan Carr, who vowed to take on 'censorship' by Big Tech companies in Project 2025, as FCC chairman
item.description: Carr, the senior Republican commissioner on the Federal Communications Commission, laid out an aggressive agenda in Project 2025 and has vowed in recent days to challenge Facebook, Google, Apple and Microsoft, which he called a “censorship cartel.”

item.title: The mysterious Virginia mansion allegedly bought with stolen Nigerian money
item.description: The way Nigerian authorities tell it, their country’s former national security adviser misappropriated more than $2 billion from his own government, routing some of it to a family friend: the man who bought the mansion in McLean. The allegations against him, experts say, underscore a significant global issue: The U.S. real estate market has become a money-laundering haven for corrupt officials and criminals across the world.

item.title: The Bills’ Josh Allen and the burden of the modern franchise quarterback
item.description: Allen, Buffalo’s Atlas, is carrying the Bills more than ever as they get set to face their longtime nemesis, the two-time defending Super Bowl champion Kansas City Chiefs, yet again.

item.title: Biden has authorized Ukraine to use long-range weapons inside Russia, senior officials say, a significant reversal of U.S. policy
item.description: The decision to allow Kyiv to use the Army Tactical Missile System, or ATACMS, to hit targets inside Russia comes as thousands of elite North Korean troops have been sent to Kursk to bolster Moscow’s forces. Russian President Vladimir Putin in September declared that the use of long-range missiles would change “the very essence, the nature of the conflict,” warning that his country would retaliate.

item.title: Still need to finish this weekend’s On the Record? We’ve got you.
item.description: Play now to finish out your score for the week.

item.title: Crossword and a coffee: Solve the Sunday puzzle now
item.description: Crossword and a coffee: Solve the Sunday puzzle now

item.title: Bela Karolyi, who coached Olympic gymnastics superstars and polarized his sport, dies at 82
item.description: Karolyi and his wife, Martha, came to prominence in their native Romania when Nadia Comaneci scored a historic perfect 10. Karolyi later led the United States to gymnastics superstardom with athletes such as Mary Lou Retton and Kerri Strug.

item.title: Trump's Defense pick Pete Hegseth paid sexual assault accuser but denies wrongdoing, attorney says
item.description: The lawyer said Hegseth paid an accuser as part of a nondisclosure agreement but maintained that their sexual encounter was consensual. President-elect Donald Trump's transition team has been unsettled by a memo shared with them by a woman who said she is a friend of the accuser, describing in detail the 2017 incident at a California hotel. Police investigated Hegseth on the sexual assault allegation but prosecutors did not file charges.

item.title: Trump chooses Chris Wright, an oil industry CEO and Trump donor who questions aspects of climate change, as energy secretary
item.description: Wright, chairman of the board of Liberty Energy, runs a foundation focused on dispelling the conventional wisdom on climate change and promoting expanded fossil energy production. His views are at odds with many climate scientists and some top energy executives, who endorse curbing greenhouse gas emissions in tune with the Paris climate agreement.

item.title: Four nights a week, scientists go out to kill owls. Their goal: saving owls.
item.description: The federal government plans to shoot up to nearly half a million barred owls throughout the West Coast. Scientists in Northern California who have been doing this nocturnal hunting for years say it is the only way to save the northern spotted owl from extinction.

item.title: Ask Sahaj: My ex’s mom blackmailed him into breaking up with me
item.description: Ask Sahaj: My ex’s mom blackmailed him into breaking up with me
